text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with Hanalei de bordeaux that's
right they said these crispy baked
custer's were impossible to make unless
you use specially designed pans or molds
but you know what they say a lot of
things so I tried it anyway and it
worked it worked real good so if you
only remember one thing from this video
it's to never believe anything they say
because usually nothing more than your
standard muffin pan I was able to create
one of the world's most unique and
delicious treats so with that let's go
ahead and get started with this very
simple batter which will begin with some
all-purpose flour as well as an equal
amount of sugar we're also gonna toss in
two egg yolks and a big pinch of salt
and then we'll finish up with some real
and pure vanilla extract as well as a
couple tablespoons of rum dark rum is
traditional but all I had was white and
it worked beautifully and then once all
that's in there we'll take a spatula and
sort of mix and smear this into a smooth
paste as you first start doing this is
gonna seem kind of dry but you'll see
just keep smearing and mixing and
eventually it will turn into sort of a
moist paste which is basically what I
have right here and we will simply keep
at that until we can't see any more
flour and at that point we'll stop and
prepare the milk and butter mixture
we're going to add to this so let's head
to the stove where we will add some
butter and whole milk to a saucepan that
will set over medium-high heat and all
we need to do is bring this up to a
simmer but we're not going to cook it as
soon as that does start to simmer and it
looks like this we'll go ahead and pull
it off the heat and add it to our Bowl
but in two additions so what we'll do
first is pour in about half and whisk
that in and then add the rest and the
fancy culinary term for this is
tempering the theory being if we added
it all once there might be so much heat
that it might cook the egg yolk so to
play it safe will add just about half
and stir that until it's smooth at which
point we can dump in the rest and we
will continue whisking until we have a
very thin very smooth batter and if
everything's gone according to plan you
should end up with something that looks
like this okay no lumps and as I said
pretty thin
so that is looking just about right and
at this point we can move on to the key
step in this entire operation prepping
our pan which as I said earlier is not
going to be fancy French canel√© molds
but simply a good old-fashioned muffin
tin and what we need to do to prep this
is grease it generously with butter and
this beeswax oh yeah that is the secret
ingredient that makes the candle a so
magical and you have to make sure you're
using pure beeswax all right this one
was sold as a wood conditioner because
it's for cutting boards but check the
label and make sure you're not getting
anything else okay it has to be pure
food grade beeswax and depending on how
it was processed and filtered it can
range anywhere from an almost clear to a
golden yellow color and you should find
this at your fancier grocery stores but
if you can't check the hardware store
since they often carry it and what we'll
do over medium heat is melt equal parts
of that with butter and as soon as that
melts we'll give it a stir with our
pastry brush and that's it as soon as
all that melts and we stir it together
it is now ready to remove from the heat
and brush into our molds or in our case
muffin tin and we really do want to be
generous here okay so is the Louie
Vuitton of how much to brush on you're
responsible for making sure the bottom
is well coated as are the sides all the
way to the top and by the way I only did
six because I didn't think there's any
chances it was gonna work but in the
blog post I'll give you the recipe for
12 but anyway we'll go ahead and butter
and wax our pan and when you're done it
should look something like this and then
once that set we'll go ahead and
carefully laid a little batter and as
usual we will portion that as evenly as
possible and there should be enough to
come up almost but not quite to the top
and by the way if you are only doing 6 I
always think it's better to stay in the
middle of the pan but anyway we will
ladle in our batter at which point these
are ready for the oven so at this point
we'll go ahead and transfer those into
the center of a 450 degree oven but only
for 10 minutes all right we'll start
them off hot and then what we'll do
after 10 minutes is reduce our heat to
375 and continue on at that time for
about 50 minutes or so or until very
well browned like very very well browned
and it first
Glantz it might look it but those have
not gone too far okay it's absolutely
critical they browned at least this much
otherwise you're not gonna get that
crispy crust and as they say in France a
can delay is not a can delay without the
crispy crust and you'll see even after
baking that long the centers are still
gonna have a little bit of softness to
them so the point is don't be scared
make sure these cook long enough and
then what we'll do at this point is let
them sit for exactly five minutes before
carefully removing from the pan and
inverting onto a rack and even though
we're not going to get the fancy fluted
edges because we didn't use the actual
moulds I still think these come out
looking absolutely stunning I'm sure
there's some French pastry chefs with
their nose in the air but that's okay
they always look like that and then
speaking of the ones done in the actual
molds because of the way they're shaped
these usually end up with like a deep
dimple in the top that I will simulate
by simply poking them gently with my
finger and that's it all we're left with
is the hardest part letting these cool
down completely before we eat them and
while the insides are gonna stay
relatively tender as these cool that
outside crust is going to get extremely
crispy and once cooled they should sound
a little something like this and
basically what's happened is that butter
and beeswax is fused to the batter and
created a crispy surface that you will
not get in any other pastry at least
that I know of but anyway we'll let
those cool at which point we'll serve
them up maybe next to a pot of coffee
and let me go ahead and cut one of these
open and we will give you a little
preview on what you have to look forward
to which is hopefully one of the more
delicious things you've ever had and it
really is the contrast between that
tender rum scented custardy part and
that sort of chewy crispy crunchy
exterior it really is so unique I mean I
really could have eaten like four of
these which of course I didn't do and
even though real canele are tall and
thin and these are sort of short and fat
to me that really didn't take away
anything from these so while arguably
maybe not quite as beautiful the fact
that we can simply make these in a
muffin tin more than makes up for that
so maybe after you finish watching this
video you can do a search and see what
these are supposed to look like
and then decide if it's worth getting
the pan but anyway that's it will may
end up one day being called American
canele or not we'll see but whether you
buy the fancy molds or just use a muffin
tin I really do hope you give these a
try soon so head over to food wishes
comm for all the ingredient amounts of
more info as usual and as always enjoy
[Music]
